entry.title: United States Tax depreciation calculations in SAP
entry.content:
Hello All, 

We are using non SAP system (SAGE) for calculating United States tax depreciation.   We did not use SAP to calculate tax depreciation because we saw some shortcomings in SAP's capability to deal with MACR and mid quarter conventions.   Pls inform if you have strong positive or strong negative views on SAP's capability to handle US tax depreciation.  

Some specific scenarios as below:-

"

Point 1:   As we mentioned, Bonus depreciation is booked at the moment we put the asset in service and reported completely as part of accumulated depreciation in further quarterly reporting. For example here $60,000 is the bonus depreciation booked on capitalization date so on further quarter report whole $60,000 should be reported as part of accumulated depreciation but when we are execute the report as on 30.06.2022 system considers only proportional amount i.e. $30,000 as part of accumulated depreciation which is not correct.

Point 2:   Normal depreciation for current year is calculated $2,000 which is correct so as on 30.06.2022, proportional depreciation should be $1000 but system reports it as 0 which is incorrect. Total accumulated depreciation as on 30.06 should be $61,000( total bonus dep. i.e. $60,000 + proportional ordinary depreciation for 6 months i.e. $1,000)

entry.content:
@SreekanthSurampally  - I got it, what you are referring and I will update the blog to clarify it.

Option 1: Remote Tables: Data will be federated (delta share) from FOS layer into Datasphere Ingestion space. 

Output: Remote table

Option 2: Replication flow to Local Tables: Data will be replicated from FOS layer into Datasphere Ingestion space.

Output: Local Table(Delta enabled) and Replication Flow

 

Hope this helps - Jeet

entry.title: Overview, IAM, Cutover Plan -Bulgaria EUR Transition for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Live Customers
entry.content:
This is only relevant for Partners and Live Customers who are required to transit Production system data with EUR adoption in Bulgaria. In the first session offered by ASC Cloud ERP Expertise Services,  3 main topics are covered, General Overview, Authorizations and Access Management, and Cutover Plan Template.

  • Recording on August 12, 2025 Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Overview)
  • Presentation on August 12, 2025 Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Overview)
  • Accelerator
    • Cutover Template Download
    • Authorizations and Access Management Guide

1. Key Discussion Points‌

1.1 Project Background & Transition Process‌

Objective‌: Facilitate Bulgaria’s transition from BGN to EUR for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers by January 2026.

Critical Steps‌:

Pre-November 2025 (CBC Customers only)‌:
  • Create a new company code with EUR and leverage SAP Incident  (unconfirmed Company code status until SAP assigns EUR currency).
  • Deploy changes post-ticket closure.
Post-November 2025(CBC Customers only)‌‌:
  • Best practice content (Cloud Release 2508.3) will automate EUR company code creation.

Solution Builder Customers‌: Must wait until November for updates.

1.2 IAM Adjustments‌

Authorization Updates‌:

  • Copy existing business roles, replace old company code references with EUR values.
  • Use ‌Mass Change Wizard‌ for bulk updates (company code, profit center, etc.).
  • Test roles in development/test systems before production deployment.

1.3 Finance & Data Migration (Cutover Plan)‌

  • Master Data‌: Extend GL accounts, house banks & bank accounts, tax conditions, profit centers, cost centers, fixed assets, bank determination to payment methods, liquidity item queries, business partners, to new company code.
  • Transactional Data‌: Migrate open items (AP/AR, GL, fixed assets postings) via ‌Migration Cockpit‌.
  • Key Checks‌:
    • Block old company code post-closing activities.
    • Validate currency exchange rates and reference currency settings.
    • Check view “Set Validity of Organizational Unit” in Document and Compliance Reporting settings
    • Copy “Cash Journal” settings from BGN to EUR
    • Set up interest rates and reference interest rates for EUR
    • Set up your Situation Handling and Teams & Responsibilities for new company code

1.4 FAQs Highlight‌

  • Transport Dependencies‌: CBC transports must follow creation sequence (Bulgaria-related TRs first).

2. Live Questions & Answers

Topic Area

Question

Answer

Group Reporting

"Group reporting is not covered in cutover activities. Will there be a dedicated session for this?"

Cutover Excel sheet will include group reporting updates, enhanced in download version

Company Code Activation

"Should we activate the new company code now or wait until November?"

For CBC customers:

  • Tickets mandatory until November (SAP assigns EUR).
  • Post-November: Once you receive the contents and updates in November, you can create the new company code with EUR as default on your own yourself.  but you CANNOT do any scope extension/ add scope for BG until conversion to 3SL happens. 

Company Code Configuration

"Is an SAP ticket required for activation, or can we self-configure?"

Depends on business criticality: Start now for January operations; wait if flexibility allows.

Transport Requests

"Will Bulgaria-related TRs create dependencies with other project TRs?"

Complete existing TRs before 2508 release upgrade. Handle Bulgaria TRs sequentially with strict access controls.

Controlling Area Currency

"Does the controlling area currency need updating for single-company-code systems?"

Group currency cannot be changed post-setup. Reprovisioning needed if LEV was original currency.

Audit Corrections

"How to handle audit corrections (e.g., depreciation) post-migration?"

Retain limited access to old company code for reporting until audits conclude (July 2026).

Professional Services

"Will there be a session for Professional Services LOB?"

No standalone session planned. Questions may be addressed in upcoming supply chain/finance sessions.

3. Call-to-Action

Register and Attend Upcoming Webinar presented by SAP Service experts' with practical suggestions
  • [Aug 20th] Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Supply Chain & SD & Procurement)  
  • [Aug 27th] Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Data Migration)
  • [Sept 3rd] Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Finance)
Please view all content and raise questions with tag #Bulgaria

entry.title: SAP Digitel Backbone related query
entry.content:
In DRAL client having S/4 HANA 2023, SAP NW JAVA (PO), SAP Contente Server, & SAP Solution Manager 7.2 SP 20 - Digital Backbone configuration not available in the client landscape due to security policy of DRAL. However, SAPROUTER is configured on 3299 and running only for R/3 Connection in case any issue. 

We have done note implementation and correction notes manually for migration. Also, install new Solman system as per the client requirement for EWA report. 

We installed Solution Manager and done the Basic, & EWA configuration without Digital Backbone. After configuration we unable to received EWA report over mail. 

Below are the questions related to Digital backbone and EWA part.  

1) Without Backbone configuration should we generate the EWA report of Manage System? Yes/No.

2) If yes, please let us know the way or guide. So, will proceed and provide EWA to client.  

I hope above information is sufficient for you. If you need more details please let us know.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP Digitel Backbone related query
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

Greetings from SAP EWA Support team.
Regarding your concern, here are the answers.

Q: Without Backbone configuration should we generate the EWA report of Manage System? Yes/No.
=> Local EWA generation in your solman is possible. However, it's not recommended to do that if you don't configure SAP Backbone. Because a lot of manual actions are required, for example, manually importing service definitions into your solman and managed systems(see KBA  727998 - Complete Replacement of Service Definitions for SDCCN) and always keep addon ST-SER & ST-PI&ST-A/PI in your solman up-to-date.

If you want to generate an EWA and send it to your clients via e-mail in your solman, please check the following EWA configuration KBAs:
2729186 - General Process of EWA Generation in SAP Solution Manager 7.2
2282944 - EarlyWatch Alert: Solution Manager 7.2 how to setup/configure EWA reports or add email recipients
2531994 - T/S Guide: EarlyWatch Alerts (EWA) reports in Solution Manager 7.2 not being sent by email 

Besides, ensure SDCCN is well configured in both solman and managed systems.

 763561 - Service Data Control Center (SDCCN) - FAQ

3240017 - SDCCN - Activation and Basic Setup for Managed Systems

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Define the selection method for the new business rule scenario following the deprecation of the 'Bas
entry.content:
みなさん

2024 年リリース前半以降、「基本」シナリオを使用して新しいビジネス ルールを作成できなくなりました。

参考:
基本ルール作成の削除 |SAP ヘルプポータル

The ability to create new rules using the "Basic" rule scenario was deprecated on November 17, 2023, and was removed on June 2, 2024.
この変更は、新しいビジネスルールの作成に影響を与えるだけでなく、場合によっては以前に作成したルールの更新が必要になる場合があります。

このような状況に備えて、「要件によるビジネスルールシナリオの選択」というタイトルのリファレンスリストを作成する予定です。
例えば、
管理手当を入力するときに、一貫性が保たれていない場合は、エラーメッセージが表示されます。→ この場合は、「HRIS 要素の検証」シナリオを使用します。

皆様の洞察とご協力を賜りますようお願い申し上げます。
このスレッドを、ビジネスルールシナリオの選択をマスターするための頼りになるリソースにしましょう。

entry.title: Re: SAC Story - Dropdown for property of Date dimension.
entry.content:
Thanks @N1kh1l,

I learnt a small trick today. I have always been frustrated that manipulating a global array variable in a script does not update any bound controls. As per the SAP documentation here, there is a note that "Push, pop or index of array in scripting won’t be reflected in the bound widget", so I had just lived with the limitation. My previous workaround was to populate a local script variable, then assign this to the global once populated. However, I was surprised when I saw your supplied code worked.

It appears the trick is to re-initialise the global variable first in the script.

So the following code WON'T work. Even though it does populate the global variable (seen in console.log or debug), the drop-down will not be updated:

// Define the base months
var monthNums = ["01","02","03","04","05","06","07","08","09","10","11","12"];

// Loop through each month from 1 to 12.
for (var i = 0; i < monthNums.length; i++) {
  // Concatenate the Year + Month and add to array.
  DD_Month.push(Sel_Year + monthNums[i]);
}

While this code DOES work. The only addition is the re-initialisation of the global, even though it is already initialised:

// Define the base months
var monthNums = ["01","02","03","04","05","06","07","08","09","10","11","12"];

// Initialize DD_Month variable
DD_Month = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

// Loop through each month from 1 to 12.
for (var i = 0; i < monthNums.length; i++) {
  // Concatenate the Year + Month and add to array.
  DD_Month.push(Sel_Year + monthNums[i]);
}

 Cheers, Ivan.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud SM: The New Data Management Screen – Part 1/2
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!  

I’m here to share with you the exciting new features and enhancements in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (PaPM) Standard Model made available and can already experience in your SAP PaPM SM tenants.  

One of the most used applications currently offered by SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud - SM is the  Show screen. As an overview, the Show screen in PaPM Cloud – SM displays the function results in a tabular form where the users can do filtering, selections, pivoting and groupings that can be used for reporting.

Apart from displaying data, the users can also perform data maintenance via the Show screen of an Editable Query function and via Manage Data of a Model Table function with Transport Data set to YES/NO and of course downloading of data for all functions. 

For your reference, you can revisit SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2024-01-03? 

In this blog post, I am thrilled to walk you through the newest enhancements in the application for better user experience in terms of data maintenance. Before we begin, please note that all scenarios discussed in this blog post will be from the perspective of the Model Table function. A separate blog post will be released later, focusing on the Editable Query function, which will cover analytical privileges, fixed selections, and data slice locking as well as the usage of display options in master data fields.  

Before we get started, this topic will be divided in two parts. Part 1, will focus mainly in the UI changes for the new Data Management screen as well as for the uploading and downloading of a file, and Part 2 will be focused on the different scenarios while uploading in the new Data Management Screen. 

So, let’s get started! 

In line with the introduction of Manage Data for the Model Table function, the Data Maintenance screen is now referred to as the Data Management screen which is already available in the App help portal.

The users can maximize the full benefit of the new Data Management screen when uploading and downloading files using a Model Table or an Editable Query function with its optimized performance. 

Access to the Data Management screen 

Prerequisites: Access to Data Management screen requires certain roles to be configured beforehand.  

For reference, you may visit the following blog posts and documentation: 

  • Role Overview in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model (Part 1/2)  
  • Role Overview in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model (Part 2/2) 
  • Help Portal Role Template for Standard Model. 

Previously, authorized users could access, manage and/or maintain data in the Show and Analyze screens through two different buttons.

Upon access to the Show and Analyze screens, the URL parameters display: 

Show screen:

Analyze screen:

With the new Data Management screen, Show and Analyze screens were merged into one screen, which can be accessed via Manage Data button.

Users can now analyze or view data in pivot by toggling on and off the Pivot button under Settings.

Upon initial access to the Data Management screen of a Model Table function, users will see the user interface and the following header buttons:

  1. Menu button 
  2. Collapse Header 
  3. General (App-Refresh) 
  4. Edit  
  5. Validation counter 
  6. Layout 
  7. Upload & Download 
  8. Settings
  9. Columns
  10. Filters  
  11. Drag and drop button 
  12. Function Description and Total Rows Count 
  13. Message Logs footer 

If the Model Table function doesn’t have an existing dataset, the user will see the Drag and Drop interface as an initial view.

Uploading File  

In the Data Management screen, the authorized users, referenced in the prerequisites can upload files (CSV and XLSX) with malware scanning limit of 400MB in two ways:

  1. Via Upload File – The users can upload a file by choosing the Upload file button in the Upload & Download header. 
  2. Via Drag and Drop – The users can simply drag the desired file from the user’s local file manager and drop it to the designated area on the screen.  

Note: Only csv and xlsx files are supported during upload and a validation error “Unsupported file type. Please use .csv, .xlsx.” will be encountered in case the user attempts to upload other local file format.

Once data upload is confirmed, the Data Upload window with the following fields sections below should be maintained and/or defined.  

  1. Number Format – this dropdown list will allow the user to choose different number format options 
  2. Date Format – this dropdown list will allow the user to choose different date format options 
  3. Time Format – this dropdown list will allow the user to choose different time format options 
  4. Field Delimiter – this field will only be available if the file to be uploaded is a csv file which allows the user to choose the field delimiter accordingly. Examples of field delimiter available are: Comma, Semicolon, Tab, Space and Pipe. 
  5. Skip header row in file during import
    - if this option is checked, the header row of the local file to be uploaded will be skipped
    - if this option is unchecked, the header row of the local file to be uploaded will be included during upload
  6. Add data from file to existing this – if this option is checked the data to be uploaded will just be added in the existing dataset
  7. Overwrite the existing data –if this option is checked, the data to be uploaded will overwrite the existing data
    - Overwrite filtered data with data from file - his option becomes active when you apply filters in the Data Management screen. If you check this option, the uploaded data overwrites the filtered data. 
  8. Cancel upload– if this button is chosen, the Data Upload window will be closed 
  9. Upload – if this button is chosen, the upload process will start

Note: The format settings to be defined in the Data Upload window should be aligned with the format of the local file that is to be uploaded. After successful upload, the formats will obtain the formats maintained in User Preferences application. 

To cover the different scenarios for uploading, please check our Data Management screen – Part 2/2. 

Downloading File  

The data download options for the new Data Management screen were enhanced for the users to be able to have a clear view of what is going to be downloaded. Data download can be performed in different ways for both csv and xlsx files with below field sections:

  1. Complete dataset – this option allows the user to download all number of rows considering the applied formatting (columns selection, filtering, and sorting). This option is not limited to the loaded and/or visible data and has the option to enable/disable applied formats. 
      - "Apply formatting checked": this will allow the user to download the dataset including the applied formatting in the screen
      - "Apply formatting unchecked": this will allow the user to download the whole dataset and will disregard the applied formatting in the screen  
  2. Visible dataset – this option allows the user to download only all loaded visible data shown in the screen. This is also the only download option available when Pivot Mode is enabled. 
    Note: The dataset is being loaded by batches of 500 rows
  3. Tooltip messages – hovering over these tooltip messages will give the user an information about Target download options
  4. File Format – If there are file formats available in the system, they can be used when downloading data. 
  5. Download CSV – this option will allow the user to download the file in CSV format 
  6. Download XLSX – this option will allow the user to download the file in XLSX format

Note: Just a heads-up, when Data Management screen is in Pivot mode On, the UI of Data Download will be a little bit different, since only the Visible dataset option will be available for use, and with this the Download with File Format will be disabled as well.  

 

And that’s it! That concludes my blog post. I hope you enjoy the new features of the new Data Management screen and be able to help you work efficiently in managing your data. To always be in the loop for more exciting news, please follow and check the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud SM: The New Data Management Screen – Part 2/2
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!

As promised, after The New Data Management Screen – Part 1/2 blog post, I’m back with Part 2/2 blog post, where we will focus on the different scenarios for uploading in the new Data Management screen.

So, without further delay, let’s get started.

Upload Overwrite Warnings

To help prevent accidental data loss, the Data Management screen now includes a clear warning whenever an upload overwrite option is selected.

Depending on your chosen upload method (Options Overwrite all existing data with data from file or Overwrite filtered data with data from file), you'll be notified if:

  1. All existing data will be overwritten, or
  2. Only specific rows (X rows currently displayed in the table- filtered ones) will be replaced.

This added layer of confirmation helps ensure you're always aware of the impact before proceeding with an upload.

Let me show you some example scenarios below to visualize the new UI.

Prerequisite: User should access an empty Data Management screen of Model Table or editable Query function.

SCENARIO 1: Uploading via Upload file in an empty screen

In case that user is to upload file in an empty screen, the Data Upload window will pop up after choosing a file.

  1. In the Data Management screen, choose Upload file button from the header.
  2. Choose a file from the File Manager, then choose Open.
  3. Maintain the appropriate format settings (Number Format, Date Format, Time Format) in the Data Upload window.
  4. Choose Confirm.

 

SCENARIO 2: Upload via Drag & Drop with an empty screen

User can either click anywhere on the Drag and drop interface or drag the local file and drop it to the designated area on the screen.

  1. In the Data Management screen, click anywhere on the Drag and drop interface or simply drag the local file and drop it to the screen.
  2. Maintain the appropriate format settings (Number Format, Date Format, Time Format) in the Data Upload window.
  3. Choose Confirm.

SCENARIO 3: Uploading via Upload File/Drag and drop with an existing data

In case the user uploads a file with existing data on the screen, the Drag and drop window will pop up.

  1. In the Data Management screen, choose Upload file button from the header.
  2. Click anywhere on the Drag and drop window or simply drag and drop file to the window.
  3. Maintain the appropriate format settings (Number Format, Date Format, Time Format) in the Data Upload window.
  4. Choose Confirm.

SCENARIO 4: Uploading with invalid data formats

In case that user defined incorrect data formats (number, time, and date formats) in the Data Upload window, or if the local file uploaded has invalid data values such as incorrect data length or out of master data, the user will be redirected to the Upload Preview tab.

While in the Data Management screen, the Go To -> Upload Preview button will be visible in the upper right of the screen once there’s an existing upload draft which redirect the user to Upload Preview tab.

Note: In case user maintained incorrect field delimiter (for csv file), the user will not be redirected to the Upload Preview tab, instead an error will be encountered, and upload will not push through.

In the Upload Preview, the user will see the following header buttons and info:

  1. Finalize & Discard
    • Finalize data upload – this button allows the user to save all the corrected data. Once chosen, the Finalize data upload warning message window will pop up where the user can choose to either finalize the data upload or cancel the action.
    • Discard data upload – this button allows the user to cancel the upload draft. If in any case there is already corrected data, the Discard data upload warning message window will pop up where the user can choose to either Continue or Cancel the discard action.
  2. Go To -> Manage Data – Choose this Go To button if you wish to go back to the Data Management screen.
  3. Validation table information – this section presents the number of rows to be corrected as well as the valid rows to be uploaded. Note that this changes accordingly once the user corrects row cells with valid data.
  4. Field column headers settings:
    - Replace in all rows -  this setting allows the user to correct values in bulk in each field column
    - Header column settings - this setting allows the user to perform column sizing and column pinning 
  5. Columns Panel – this panel helps the user to perform column management of fields in the data table.

SCENARIO 5: Automatic saving of Upload Preview draft

In case of unexpected termination, for example: browser/system shutdown or the user accidentally accesses a different application screen, the upload draft is automatically saved and can be accessed by the user who initiated the upload process.

In this way, the user won’t have to worry about losing the draft that was already corrected in the Upload Preview. A warning message “Upload for this table hasn't been finalized yet. Go to upload preview” will pop-up or Go to -> Upload Preview is enabled in the header as an indication that there’s an existing upload draft.

Once the user chooses any of the upload preview links, user will be redirected to the upload preview tab where draft will be present. In this screen the user is allowed to edit the data to correct the erroneous data.

Note: Once the last erroneous value is edited, the upload will be automatically finalized, and the user will be redirected to Data Management screen.

SCENARIO 6: Locking Mechanism in Upload Preview

Data Management is made more efficient with its locking mechanism feature during the upload process in the Data Management of the same Model Table, editable Query function or any related Queries derived from the same Model Table, for example:

       6A: User A has started an upload process in the Data Management or updating upload draft in Upload Preview and User B attempts to upload a file in the same function, User B will encounter a warning message pop-up “Another user is editing this data. Upload action is not possible now.”

6B: In case that User A will be on idle or is not changing anything in the Upload Preview, an active timer message window “Finalize data upload” will pop-up after 12 minutes of being idle and/or inactive to inform the user of the remaining time (3 minutes) before the draft will be discarded automatically. User A will have two options:

  1. Finalize Upload – this option is equivalent to the Finalize data upload button from the header button finalizing upload and saving all valid data rows.
  2. I need more time – this option allows the user to reset the already calculated idle time, providing an additional 15 minutes before the draft is discarded.

User A will be redirected to the Upload Preview. At this point, uploading of file is not possible for User B.

Note: Upload action will trigger application run type: DATA_IMPRT in the Application log monitor, if the user is still in the Upload Preview, the status will show “Awaiting User Input”. The status will change to Success if the draft is successfully saved or Abort if the upload draft is discarded.

SCENARIO 7: Upload with file formats

Just like in old Show screen, you can upload CSV and XLSX files in the Data Management screen using predefined file formats. This makes managing your data quicker and more accurate, especially when working with different date, time, and number formats.

Previously, in the Show screen, clicking the Upload icon allowed you to select a file from your local, and then a dialog would appear where you could choose the sheet (for XLSX) or specify the file format to be used during the upload.

Now, when you go to the Data Management screen and click Upload, you’ll first be taken to a Select File Format dialog. From here:

  • You can either choose Continue without file format, where upon clicking Continue, you will be redirected to Data Upload screen, where you can choose the predefined formats already existing in the system (same as the ones available in User Preferences).

Note: Always remember that in case Number, Date and Time Formats are incorrect (not the same format as the XLSX/CSV file to be uploaded) the Upload Preview will be triggered, since these formats need to be aligned with the file to be uploaded.

  • You can choose an existing file format from the dropdown (by clicking the arrow next to “File Format”). Once you click Continue, you’ll land on the familiar Data Upload screen, where you can finalize your upload.

Note: The Data Upload UI will also change accordingly, in case the user is uploading a XLSX or CSV file.

Let’s look at some common upload scenarios while using file formats:

  1.  Uploading a CSV with the correct file format 

If your file format settings match the CSV content — great! The upload will complete successfully with no issues.

       2. Uploading a CSV with the wrong file format

If the file format selected in the Data Upload on Data Management screen doesn’t match the data in the CSV to be uploaded, the system will detect it and trigger the Upload Preview screen.

In this scenario let’s say that the thousand and the decimal separator are not matching between the file format in the modeling and the data of the CSV to be uploaded.

Upon uploading the CSV file this will trigger the Upload Preview screen, since the file format in the system do not match the formats used in the file. You’ll be able to see exactly where the mismatches are, so you can correct them in Upload Preview or simply cancel the upload and adjust your file format settings to match the required ones from the file.

Note: Make sure your Field Delimiter, Date, Time, Timestamp Formats and Thousand and Decimal Separators all match what's in your file.

       3. Uploading XLSX with correct file format

If the format settings match the content of your XLSX file, the upload will work seamlessly.

Note: For XLSX files, the Field Delimiter setting in the file format is not taken into consideration.

       4. Uploading XLSX with the wrong file format

If the file format selected in the Data Upload doesn’t match the data in the XLSX to be uploaded, the system will detect it the Upload Preview screen will be triggered.

In this scenario, let’s say that the date format is not matching between the file format in the modeling and the data of the XLSX to be uploaded.

Like what happen when uploading a CSV with incorrect format, the data can be edited in the Upload Preview or cancel the upload and adjust the file format settings to match the required ones from the file.

Note: Always pay attention to the Date and Time Formats applied in the File Formats section in the Modeling. DD/MM/AAAA or yyyy as a date format or hh as time format will not be accepted since this is not supported according to HANA docs. The use of file formats can be applied in the same way in both Pivot mode off and on.

And this is it for this blog post. I hope you enjoyed the new features.

Watch out for new features for the Data Management screen to be released soon.

Stay tuned for more exciting news by following the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: How Putaway Strategy Works in EWM RFUI Bin-to-Bin Transfers
entry.content:
In one of my projects, a customer asked for a simple improvement: “Can the system suggest the destination bin automatically during bin-to-bin transfers?” I had seen similar cases which was solved with custom developments. But we can do it entirely with standard EWM.

This blog post will guide you on how to set it up and why it’s worth considering for your processes.

Most warehouses already use putaway strategies for inbound processes. With a small configuration change, the same logic can be applied to internal movements without creating a delivery or triggering a warehouse task first.

Key benefits:

  1. No need to create a delivery; You can still apply putaway strategies directly.

  2. Works right after synchronous goods receipt; Strategies are applied immediately after receiving the goods.

  3. No need to trigger a putaway warehouse task; This saves valuable time in daily operations.

In short, less clicking, less waiting, and smoother warehouse operations.

In standard EWM RF screens for creating and confirming Ad Hoc Handling Unit (HU) Warehouse Tasks (WT) and Ad Hoc Product Warehouse Tasks (WT), you will get an error as below if you try to get a bin suggestion without any putaway strategies configured.

/SCWM/PUT_BIN_DET039

Configuration Steps;

The key configuration points are:

  • Define Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

  • Assign Storage Types to Storage Type Search Sequence

  • Specify Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

Here, we can catch the putaway strategy in many ways, such as storage control, process type, product group, stock type/group, etc.

If we want to capture the putaway strategy from process type;

 

If you want to use different putaway strategy for different products you can use the Putaway Control Indicator field both in the search sequence and in product maintenance /SCWM/MAT1 as below.

Testing;

 

After creating and assigning the putaway strategy, the Ad Hoc Product Warehouse Tasks screen works in two steps:

  • The system suggests a destination storage bin in the original bin field on the second screen.

  • This screen appears after pressing Enter in the Destination Bin field on the first screen.

To reduce this two-step process, we made a small change in the logical transaction flow by defining the processing mode as background and adding a background function code.

With this change, the RF bin-to-bin transfer screen now works according to the defined putaway strategy in just one step.

In conclusion, bin-to-bin transfers are a common internal process within warehouses in SAP EWM. Using the storage bin transfer together with predefined putaway strategies allows the system to automatically suggest the best destination storage bin. This not only speeds up warehouse operations but also ensures that stock is stored in the most optimal locations according to your warehouse strategies.

Thanks,

Ömer Burak Gedik

entry.title: Easily Find the Link between Deliveries ↔ Freight Orders – Thanks to a CDS View
entry.content:
The first idea might be to use the document flow (VBFA). But here, you quickly hit a wall – TM objects simply don’t show up there.

SAP has already enhanced some classic transactions, like the Outbound Delivery Monitor (VL06O), to display the related freight order.

But things get really interesting when you dig into how SAP actually retrieves this TM data.

The CDS View P_OUTBDELIVFRTORDRLTN.


This view directly provides the relationship between a delivery and a freight order – no function modules, no method calls, no overly complex joins. Just clean, simple, and performant.

Tip:
If you explore the development package VDM_TM_BO_TOR where this CDS view resides, you’ll discover plenty of other TM-related CDS treasures. Perfect for quickly building your own reports or analytics.

entry.title: Create Your First AI-Powered App in SAP Build Code with Joule and Generative AI
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Generative AI is revolutionizing the way developers create applications, and SAP is at the forefront of this change. With tools like SAP Build Code and Joule, developers can dramatically speed up the entire development lifecycle — from designing data models to building intuitive user interfaces — achieving in minutes what once took weeks. This fusion of AI-powered intelligence and SAP’s enterprise-grade capabilities empowers teams to innovate faster, reduce manual effort, and deliver high-quality applications that drive real business value.

Step 1. Introduction to SAP Build Code and Joule

What is SAP Build Code?

SAP Build Code is part of the SAP Build family, enabling pro-code developers to:

  • Build clean-core compliant extensions
  • Use SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)
  • Leverage AI-assisted code generation via Joule
  • Integrate with both SAP and non-SAP systems

It’s deeply integrated into SAP BTP and offers:

  • A built-in development environment
  • Access to APIs and services
  • Security, CI/CD, and runtime tools
  • Fusion development — collaboration between professional developers and business experts

Why Clean Core Matters

A clean core keeps your SAP S/4HANA system as close to standard as possible, enabling:

  • Faster innovation adoption
  • Easier upgrades
  • Reduced total cost of ownership
  • Improved security and performance

SAP Build Code supports this by focusing on side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP.

Where Joule Fits In

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, helps you:

  • Generate CDS data models from natural language prompts
  • Build services, sample data, and annotations automatically
  • Add business logic without manually writing all boilerplate code
  • Create UI elements through guided wizards

Step 2. Building the Employee Skill Tracker Application

The session’s mission was to build a Finance Application in minutes using:

  • SAP Build Code for development
  • CAP model for backend logic
  • Joule for AI-driven code and UI generation

With just a natural language prompt, Joule generated the entities (Employee, Skill, Project, and Certification), their attributes, and associations. The CAP service layer and Fiori UI annotations were created automatically, enabling the team to jump straight into implementing business rules such as certification expiry alerts and skill-gap detection.

Application Overview

The application allows:

  • Creating employees, skills, projects, and certifications
  • Assigning skills to employees and tracking their proficiency levels
  • Allocating employees to projects and monitoring their start/end dates and status
  • Recording employee certifications with issuer details and expiry tracking
  • Automating business rules, such as flagging upcoming certification expiries or identifying employees with required skills for open projects

Step 3. Setting Up SAP Build Code

You can set up SAP Build Code in two main ways:

  1. Set-up the SAP Build and Business Studio using Service MarketPlace
  2. Booster in SAP BTP Cockpit – Works for trial and enterprise accounts.

For this session, the trial account + booster method was used:

Created a dedicated SAP BTP subaccount with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio (BAS).
All required roles, entitlements, and services—including CAP runtime, SAP HANA Cloud, and AI-powered Joule integration—were enabled automatically, ensuring a ready-to-develop environment without any manual setup overhead.

Step 4. Creating the Full-Stack Application

Flow 1: Starting a Project

  • In the SAP Build Lobby, select Create → Application → Full Stack Application

  • Name the project, link it to a BAS Dev Space, and open it in Business Application Studio

Initially, the Employee Skill Tracker project was a blank canvas — no entities, no business logic, and no UI. Within minutes, Joule transformed it into a fully structured CAP application, complete with data models, OData services, and Fiori-ready annotations.

Flow 2: Generating the Data Model with Joule

Using a natural language prompt, Joule generated:

Entities:

  1. Employee (Name, Email, Department, Hire Date)
  2. Skill (Skill Name, Proficiency Level)
  3. Project (Project Name, Start Date, End Date, Status)
  4. Certification (Certificate Name, Issuer, Expiry Date)

Result:

  1. schema.cds for entity definitions
  2. service.cds exposing OData services for Employee management
  3. Fiori annotations for displaying employee skill matrices in a table

Example prompt snippet:

"Create a CAP data model for an "Employee Skill Tracker" application.

Entities:

  1. Employee — Fields: Name (String), Email (String), Department (String), Hire Date (Date).
  2. Skill — Fields: Skill Name (String), Proficiency Level (String).
  3. Project — Fields: Project Name (String), Start Date (Date), End Date (Date), Status (String).
  4. Certification — Fields: Certificate Name (String), Issuer (String), Expiry Date (Date).

Requirements:

  1. Use UUID as the key for all entities.
  2. Create associations so that Skills, Projects, and Certifications link to an Employee.
  3. Generate schema.cds with entity definitions and associations.
  4. Generate service.cds exposing OData services for all entities.
  5. Add Fiori UI annotations for each entity to support List Reports and Object Pages.
  6. Use titles for fields in annotations to make the UI user-friendly."

Result:

  • schema.cds with entity definitions
  • service.cds with OData service exposure
  • Fiori annotations for UI hints

Flow 3: Adding Sample Data

From the data editor:

  • Added mock data for each entity
  • Enhanced it via Joule prompt:

"Generate data/EmployeeSkillTracker.csv sample data for my CAP application with the following entities and relationships:

  1. Employee — Fields: UUID key, Name, Email, Department, Hire Date.
  2. Skill — Fields: UUID key, Skill Name, Proficiency Level, Association to Employee.
  3. Project — Fields: UUID key, Project Name, Start Date, End Date, Status, Association to Employee.
  4. Certification — Fields: UUID key, Certificate Name, Issuer, Expiry Date, Association to Employee.

Requirements:

  1. Create 5 employees with realistic names, emails, departments, and hire dates.
  2. Assign 2–3 skills per employee with varying proficiency levels (Beginner, Intermediate, Expert).
  3. Assign 1–2 projects per employee with realistic start/end dates and statuses (Planned, Active, Completed).
  4. Assign 1–2 certifications per employee with different issuers and expiry dates.
  5. Output data in CSV format compatible with CAP db/data folder.
  6. Ensure associations match using Employee UUID values."

Outcome: Meaningful, test-ready datasets.

Flow 4: Implementing Business Logic

With the core entities — Employee, Skill, Project, and Certification — in place, the next step was to add custom business logic that makes the Employee Skill Tracker truly useful.

Requirements:

  1. In the srv/employee-service.js, add the following rules:

  • Auto-assign “Onboarding” project to every new Employee when they are created, with Status = "Active" and Start Date = current date.
  • Prevent deletion of Employees if they have active projects. Show an error: "Cannot delete employee with active projects".
  • Validate Skill Proficiency Level so it must be one of: "Beginner", "Intermediate", "Expert". If not, reject with a meaningful message.
  • Auto-calculate Project Status: if the End Date is before today, set Status to "Completed".
  • Send a console log every time a new Certification is added for an Employee.

  1. Ensure logic uses CAP Node.js event handlers (before, after, on) appropriately.

  2. Output the complete srv/employee-service.js file with the implemented logic.

Joule wrote the JavaScript for these logic files directly from the prompt.

Once you click the Add button, the “Open Code Editor” option becomes visible. From here, you can leverage Joule to generate the required business logic automatically. With just a natural language prompt, Joule translates your intent into CAP service code — exactly like in the screenshot below — saving time on boilerplate and letting you focus on fine-tuning the rules.

Flow 5: Building the UI

With the backend logic ready, it was time to create an intuitive and connected user interface.

Using the SAP Build Code UI Wizard, we:

  • Generated a Fiori Elements List Report for the Employee entity to provide an at-a-glance view of all employees in the system.
  • Enabled navigation links from each employee record to their associated Skills, Projects, and Certifications, ensuring a seamless drill-down experience.
  • Configured key columns in the list report, including Department, Hire Date, and Total Skills, for quick decision-making.
  • Applied Fiori Annotations for better formatting — e.g., date pickers for Hire Date, semantic colors for project status, and quick badges for expiring certifications.

Step 5. Running the App

After dependencies installed:

  • Backend OData services and frontend UI were available instantly
  • UI showed customer list, purchases, and redemptions
  • Business logic executed when adding purchases or redemptions (reward points updated automatically)

Step 6. Key Takeaways

  • Speed: Built an Employee Skill Tracker app from scratch to a functional CAP + Fiori app in under 15 minutes using Joule-generated entities (Employee, Skill, Project, Certification).
  • AI Boost: Joule eliminated boilerplate coding, allowing the developer to focus on business logic, such as auto-generating unique Skill IDs to avoid duplicate key errors.
  • Clean Core: Entire solution is side-by-side on SAP BTP; no modifications to the core S/4HANA system, ensuring upgrade safety.
  • Scalability: Easily extendable—can add features like Skill Gap Analysis, automatic Certification Expiry alerts, or integration with S/4HANA HR and SuccessFactors for real-time employee data sync.
  • Resilience: Built-in safeguards like UUID-based keys or ID auto-generation logic prevent data conflicts and ensure smooth multi-user usage.
  • Future-Ready: Can quickly expand to mobile apps, integrate with SAP Build Process Automation for skill approval workflows, or hook into SAP Analytics Cloud for skill heatmaps.

Conclusion
Generative AI, coupled with SAP’s robust development ecosystem, is transforming how enterprise-grade applications are built. In this journey from concept to a fully functional Finance App, SAP Build Code and Joule demonstrated how AI can eliminate repetitive tasks, accelerate delivery, and uphold clean-core principles.

What once took weeks of manual coding, data modeling, and UI design now takes minutes—without compromising quality, scalability, or integration capabilities. By combining pro-code flexibility, AI-assisted development, and SAP BTP’s enterprise foundation, teams can focus on solving real business challenges instead of wrestling with technical overhead.

This is more than a productivity boost—it’s a new paradigm for how innovation happens in the SAP landscape.

entry.title: Verification of Payee (VoP) - What is planned in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Verification of Payee

1        Introduction

Starting October 5th, 2025, a new regulation by the European Payments Council (EPC) takes effect, called VoP: Verification of Payee.  The VoP needs to be considered for all SEPA payments within the EURO zone between Payment Service Providers (for non-EURO zone countries the regulation will take place in July 2027).

What does this mean? EPC tells us: 

"The European Payments Council's (EPC) Verification Of Payee (VOP) scheme is a standardized framework designed to enhance payment security across the Single Euro Payments Area (SEPA). It aims to reduce fraud and misdirected payments by verifying that the payee's name matches the account number provided before a payment is executed.

When a requester (the payer) initiates a SEPA Credit Transfer (SCT) or SEPA Instant Credit Transfer (SCT Inst), its Payment Service Provider (PSP), the requesting PSP, sends a VOP request to the payee's PSP (the responding PSP). This request includes the payee's International Bank Account Number (IBAN) and either its name or an identifier such as a VAT number or Legal Entity Identifier (LEI). 

The payee's PSP (the responding PSP) checks the provided information against its records and responds with one of the following answers:

  • Match: The name (or identifier) and IBAN correspond exactly.
  • Close Match: There are minor discrepancies, such as typographical errors.
  • No Match: The details do not correspond.
  • Verification Not Possible: The check cannot be completed. 

The payer's PSP (the requesting PSP) communicates the result to the requester (the payer), who can then decide whether to proceed with the payment or not. "

[taken from: https://www.europeanpaymentscouncil.eu/what-we-do/other-schemes/verification-payee/questions-answers-verification-payee-scheme]

But what does this mean for corporates, running SAP Cloud ERP with regards to their incoming and outgoing payments?  

First of all, there are no plans from EPC to publish standards for customer-to-bank interaction (see Question 4 at https://www.europeanpaymentscouncil.eu/what-we-do/other-schemes/verification-payee/questions-answers-verification-payee-scheme) . 

For the verification itself it is defined, that it should be executed within 5 seconds (request from one payment service provider to the other including response – see https://www.europeanpaymentscouncil.eu/faq/verification-payee-scheme/rulebook/bulk-vop-requests). However, there is no guideline for the response time between customer to bank.

As a conclusion, each bank might have its own implementation and guideline of VoP.  Also, it depends on the bank, in which way VoP will be offered. In this regard, we speak about 'opt-in' (use the new service) and 'opt-out' (do not use the service). We will see later that certain cases even force an opt-in!

For SAP Cloud ERP (as well as for other SAP instances), the connection to a house bank can be established by using SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity. 4 different channels are provided: 

- EBICS (Electronic Banking Internet Communication Standard) 

- SWIFT

- Host to host (H2H)

- Bank APIs 

Unfortunately, the different channels solve VoP in different ways. That makes it difficult for SAP as software provider to implement one solution which fits all. 

Let's have a closer look at each channel with regards to the steps of submitting the payment, analysis of verification result and approval or rejection of the payment.  

2        What we currently know for the different channels 

2.1     EBICS

2.1.1    Submission of payment

The Deutsche Kreditwirtschaft (DK) will implement VoP as of October 5th.

There will be new order types respectively a new service option within the BTF parameter for opt-in according to the following specification (please see the full specification at  https://www.ebics.de/de/ebics-standard, 2025-07-22-Mapping_EBICS-BTF-Auftragssarten-gueltig-ab-5-Oktober-2025-mAE.pdf).

This results in the following VoP options:

Service

Option

Message

Order Type

BTF Parameter*

SEPA Credit Transfer SCT

opt-out

Pain.001

CCT

SCT//VOO/pain.001 or SCT///pain.001**

SEPA Credit Transfer SCT

opt-in

Pain.001

CTV

SCI//VOI/pain.001

SEPA Instant Payment SCI

opt-out

Pain.001

CIP

SCI//VOO/pain.001 or SCI///pain.001**

SEPA Instant Payment SCI

opt-in

Pain.001

CIV

SCI//VOI/pain.001

* BTF Parameter is a set of attributes, here (Service Name/Service Scope/Service Option/MsgName)

*Providing no service option is seen as opt out.

If possible,  the pain.001 message should be provided by using a pain.001.001.09 format. See 'Appendix_3_Data_Formats_3.9.pdf' at https://www.ebics.de/de/datenformate. Old format versions like pain.001.001.03 are still supported, but run out of validity as of November 2026 (https://www.ebics.de/de/datenformate/format-lifecycle). 

The Instant Payments regulation allows corporates to waive VoP in case of bulk payments.

Conclusion: If a corporate does not use the new order types or BTF service option parameter for bulk payments, this is treated as opt-out .

However: For the case of only one payment transaction within a message, it is important to know that the instant payments regulation foresees this as a mandatory OptIn. This means that payment messages with only one payment might not be sent with the previously known order type/BTF service option parameter, as the payment service provider might reject it.

On the other hand, it seems that this will be handled differently depending on the payment service provider as some providers indicated they will also allow opt-out for such payments.  

Conclusion: 

As a corporate you need to clarify with your different payment service provider how single payments will be treated.

If you decide on opt-in, you need to update the order type resp. BTF parameter derivation for Multi-Bank Connectivity Connector to set the new values.

SAP will update the respective derivation customizing tables with an option for single payments.  Once a note is released, it will be updated here. For S/4HANA Cloud ERP we will reference the related What’s new.

2.1.2    Analysis of verification results

The VoP service foresees that the result of the verification must be shown to the requester. When the response is other than a match, the response needs to be provided as sent gy the responding PSP. Based on the response the requester decides whether to pursue or not with the payment.

With EBICS, the response can be provided by a pain.002 message. The payment status report order type list and BTF service option parameter will be enhanced accordingly.

Service

Option

Message

...

Order Type

BTF Parameter*

Report

SCI

Pain.002

...

CIZ

...

 

SCT

Pain.002

...

CRZ

...

 

VOP

Pain.002

...

VPZ

REP/DE/VOP/pain.002/ZIP

*parameter set (Service Name/Service Scope/Service Option/MsgName/Container Type)

The supported pain.002 format is pain.002.001.10 (see chapter 2.2.6 of ‘Appendix_3_Data_Formats_3.9.pdf’ at https://www.ebics.de/de/datenformate).

The status report will provide the verification status of each transaction in section <TxInfAndSts> as well as a summary of transactions per status in the section <OrgnlGrpInfAndSts> or <OrgnPmtInfAndSts>.

In SAP Cloud ERP, status reports can be received via various channels. The most common one is the integration with SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity and its Connector. Status report information can be displayed afterwards in various applications like ‘Monitor Payments’ and ‘Manage Payments’. The format pain.002.001.10 in general is already supported in SAP Cloud ERP Release 2508 as well as by SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (and Multi-Bank Connectivity Connector) .

SAP plans to update the monitors with the related verification information from the status notification. The overall status shall be shown as well at the detailed status for each transaction.

2.1.3    Approve or reject payment

After checking the verification results a decision for authorization must be made. This applies to all cases, even for a full match. 

DK defines that bulk payments (payment messages with more than one transaction) always have to be fully authorized or fully rejected. This means users can't remove suspicious items from a bulk payment without reversing the full batch payment.

With regards to EBICS, the authorization step is supported by using the Electronic Distributed Signature (EDS – in German Verteilte Elektronische Unterschrift VEU). In the case of opt-in, payments always have to be authorized via EDS. Signatures already handed in together with the payment message will be removed.

EDS is currently not supported by SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Cloud ERP Private or SAP ECC. Instead of sending the signatures separately, both payment message and signatures are sent together.

Consequently, the final authorization step cannot be triggered automatically within the SAP offerings mentioned. Instead, a user must log on to the related banking portal to authorize or reject the payment as of today.

The following graphic shows the option, where pain.002 response values are mapped to a ‘pending’ status, shown within the known S/4 apps. ‘Pending can trigger a notification, so that a business user is informed about the necessity to logon to the banking portal.

 

Alternatively, the pain.002 response values could be mapped either to a reject or accept response. This would support the automatic process, however, is valid again for the whole payment (if there is at least one transaction, which does not match, the whole batch is rejected).

However, for the final authorization it is still necessary, that the user approves the payment in the banking portal!

Both reactions on pain.002 status require a special configuration setup for SAP Cloud ERP. Please contact your SAP Cloud Success Manager.

2.1.4    Outlook

SAP plans to enhance the notifications provided by the situations framework to inform users about close matches or no-matches (see graphic above). Using the notification a business user can start afterwards the investigation to correct related master data rathen than adjusting the data directly in the payment. 

2.2     SWIFT, H2H and Bank API

As indicated beforehand, there is no common approach for these channels which is valid for multiple banks. It seems, each bank defines its own implementation of the VoP process for those channels.

2.2.1    Submission of payment

Some banks for example advice to provide a prefix in case of opt-in when providing the payment files.

At SAP Cloud ERP there are BADIs available to adjust the payment file name like described here:

Custom naming rules in payment medium files.

BADI for file name manipulation for Advanced Payment Management (link will be provided soon). 

Custom Logic

Alternatively, you could request to adjust the file naming within SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity itself by submitting a service request. 

From some Austrian Banks we know that opt-in and opt-out shall be communicated via the payment medium itself, in this case on batch level via tag <InstrForDbtrAgt> by populating a certain code (see page 25 at https://zv.psa.at/de/download/xml/kunde-bank/rb-2023/documentation-english/471-iso-pain-001-001-09-austrian-005-en-pdf/file.html).

For Portuguese banks opt-in and opt-out shall be communicated via tag <AuthStn> on file level (see https://www.bportugal.pt/sites/default/files/documents/2025-05/Manual%20de%20Comunicação%20C2PSP%20(versão%206.00)_vf.pdf – only in Portuguese).

Conclusion: 

Please check with your house bank for their specific requirements with regards to opt-in and opt-out, e.g. if they expect the information within the file or within the file name.

Please also verify if payments containing a single transaction are automatically considered as opt-in.

2.2.2    Analysis of verification results and approval/rejection of payment 

The same approach as for EBICS applies here, if the house bank can send a pain.002 status notification. This means, verification results could be shown within SAP Cloud ERP in 'Monitor Payments' and 'Manage Payments'. However, again there is no automatic trigger of an approval or rejection of the payment. This needs to be done in the banking portal. 

Conclusion: 

Please check with your house bank how they will be able to communicate the verification result and how they will handle the authorization/rejection of payments in case you decide to opt-in. 

3        Other options

To prevent last-minute validations during payment execution, banks often provide a paid service for pre-validating master data. This involves calling a bank-specific API that can be implemented.

For this Online validation framework could be used which allows validation on following places: 

  • Business partner check event
  • FI document posting
  • Partners mass check report
  • MM document posting
  • Payment run

For Slovakia, SAP offers bank account validation based on government register. It is used for a slightly different purpose. It is related to a local tax compliance rule where banks (or payment service provider) check whether the recipient’s bank account is registered with the Slovak tax authority — to help prevent VAT fraud.

entry.title: Selective Data Transition: HCM migration to the cloud
entry.content:
The private cloud edition of SAP HCM¸ which to a large extent reflects enhancement package 8, has been available since the 2022 release of S/4HANA 2022. It offers several innovations, especially in the Fiori user experience and performance. SAP HCM for S/4HANA is the successor solution to SAP HCM for ECC and can be used until 2040 at the earliest, while support for the existing HCM on ECC solution ends in 2027.  It’s important to note again at this point that customers must complete their selective data transformation (SDT) project well before the end of the maintenance support. And this is a major reason for the sense of urgency surrounding HCM transformations.

Customers who have opted for extended maintenance have more time to complete their transformation, as support won’t end until 2030. However, those who have already moved to S/4HANA with the compatibility mode should act quickly: the right to use it expires at the end of 2025. Lastly, for RISE customers, user rights terminate at the end of 2030.

Discontinued and new functions

Some of the functionalities currently in HCM may be succeeded by new functions in the S/4HANA version. This is a further urgency factor, as customers may need to plan, budget and implement a pre-project before the actual S/4HANA transition to deal with the discontinued and new functions. That’s why it’s important for customers to review and deal with these, as well as any organizational and process changes, long before their actual S/4HANA transition. The closer customers get to the end of maintenance, the harder it will be to plan and implement pre-projects – and especially to find an implementation partner to help with the work.

What are the target scenarios to consider in the transition to HCM on S/4HANA or to SuccessFactors? The bulk of the HCM innovations are reflected in SAP’s SuccessFactors public cloud solution. Many customers need more time to move to S/4HANA – so SAP has made an on-premises solution temporarily available as a result.  However, the enhancements in this solution will be limited to localized legal requirements like payroll and social insurance. The main focus of the innovations will be within the SuccessFactors solution.

Choosing between HCM on S/4HANA and SuccessFactors

Looking at SuccessFactors, why would a customer choose S/4HANA over SuccessFactors? The main reason is – again – the maintenance deadlines. For most legacy HCM customers, S/4HANA is the better choice for the simple reason that the implementation time will be much faster. They can keep their own customizations, processes, and developments, while with SuccessFactors they’ll have to recreate their architecture and redesign their processes, generating higher costs. With S/4HANA they are securing current investments – even though they may be missing out on the innovations in SuccessFactors.

Database volume reduction options

One option for customers is to simply convert their legacy HCM solution to S/4HANA. The key thing to remember here is that the simplification items – such as managers’ desktop, cost planning, recruiting and training management – are not available in S/4HANA and will be replaced with alternative solutions. For that reason, it doesn’t make sense for customers to keep obsolete data from these items in their new S/4HANA system. Instead, they only need migrate the really important applications, data and functionalities – the basis of SDT. There are cost and efficiency benefits to starting with a lean and clean S/4HANA system while significantly reducing the size of their database.

SDT is also beneficial in other ways. Prior to a transition, customers usually start with specific selection criteria, such as employee numbers, as some staff may have left the company. Probably the most important criterion is the time slice function. Many organizations have 30 years or more of payroll history in their HCM systems, whereas much of that data is unnecessary on the new system. Around 5-7 years of data is about average to enable companies to make retroactive calculations for benefit plans or other purposes. The time slice significantly reduces the size of the future S/4HANA database, even by as much as 50%.

SDT for complex, integrated systems

The SDT approach for customers with very complex HCM systems – especially when the HCM system is integrated into the ERP system – is often greenfield for the financial and controlling data. Conversely, with HCM they choose the brownfield approach because they want to protect all of the significant development investments they’ve made over the years. The greenfield and brownfield approaches can be combined into a single project, while applying SDT precepts to the HCM data. As we saw earlier, a 30-year historical database is too much for most companies, so they can limit the transitioned data to about 5-7 years and make the database much leaner.

It's important to emphasize here that SAP and its SDT Engagement partners always take local regulations into account – for example, 5 to 7 years of payroll data may be too little in some geographies. In addition, they will always align the historical HCM data to the new financial and controlling structure, as cost center information may change and need to be adapted. Having said that, SAP and its SDT Engagement partners have the tools, services, and flexibility to offer this mapping service to customers as an additional sub-project.

SuccessFactors ECP

A further option for organizations wishing to transition is a move to SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP). In this case, the customer would only migrate the relevant payroll data from their HCM system to the ECP cloud. This is also a form of SDT as the migration only applies to data based on one application. With migration to ECP, time slice is the most common SDT criterion, as it enables customers to preserve only the last few years of history for legal or audit reasons or for retroactive calculations.

How the project works

These SuccessFactors or HCM migrations are structured similarly to a normal IT project. We should emphasize here that it’s crucial to leave enough time for testing – and even to carry out the migration two or three times to be sure everything is running smoothly.

 

Phases or big bang?

With ERP transitions, go-live is often phased as organizations take one company or division live first and iron out any issues, then move on to the next phase. However, HCM differs as it requires highly consistent data, so the big bang approach is preferable. As we saw earlier, testing beforehand is the key. Customers need to be sure everything is working properly when there are no employees connected to the system, i.e. on the weekend before go-live.

Project duration and timing

The experience of SAP and its SDT Engagement partners shows that 9 to 12 months is about average if the HCM system is integrated with ERP. If HCM is standalone, the project can take as little as 6 to 9 months. Another difference from ERP projects is the timing. ERP migrations are often performed at the end of the financial year, yet this is the busiest time for HR professionals as they have a heavy workload with payroll and social insurance calculations. This is also the time that SAP brings out special support updates (so-called Christmas packages). Customers embarking on an SDT initiative can (and should) implement support packages during the project but SAP and its SDT Engagement partners recommend completing this prior to the dry-run and go-live phases.

Preparatory tasks to complete prior to project kick-off

There are a few things customers can do before the project gets started. The first is to deal with the simplification items detected by the readiness check, as these will not be available in the new system. The second key task is defining which data customers want to transfer or leave behind. The third is to check third-party tools, which are often used by the HR department. This is a crucial point because not all of them support HCM on S/4HANA. Customers should therefore contact the suppliers to ask if the tools are S/4HANA-compatible and whether there’s any adjustments they need to make. Organizations may also find that it is necessary to review the budget, resource, and implementation planning again, especially if there are functions and/or tools not supported by, or available on, the new system. Last but not least, customers should review their Fiori front-end strategy, especially as some HR systems are used by employees on a daily basis.

 

Top three tasks for customers prior to the SDT project

Next steps

The first thing customers can do now is to set up the appropriate HR IT strategy and define the system landscape (S/4HANA on-premises, which is secured at least until the end of 2040, SuccessFactors with its new functions, and HCM on S/4HANA). Customers should decide whether to go for a private or public cloud and define a rough timeline. It’s important to circle back with ERP colleagues too, as changes to data like company codes need to be reflected in the HCM system too. They can carry out a readiness check to ascertain the project duration and budget. A crucial step for customers to take now is to contact implementation partners and choose one in good time to help them with the SDT project. These specialists are already in high demand now, so this is a good place for potential customers to start!

Discover more: For more detailed information, watch the webinar recording of "SDT: How to Deal with the SAP Suite Solutions? Focus: HCM" and learn how Selective Data Transition enables not just a technical migration – but a holistic transformation that secures your HR data, streamlines processes, and delivers real business value.

After doing 101, consider using movement type 344 which transfers the unrestricted stock to Quality. Once the Business decides, they are ready, this can be reversed via 343 to move back to unrestricted. This should work well for batch-managed materials and avoids blocked stock complications.

entry.title: Re: Will the WBS PIR pick Order type from Production sche...
entry.content:
Check in material master Work Scheduling view, the Production Scheduling profile is assigned. Also, check whether the Production Scheduling Profile is assigned to Production Scheduler in OPKP.

To answer your question 'Do Strategy type affect this?', no, strategy type does affect this. Here's how:

  • Strategy type (e.g., 10, 20, 40) determines the requirement class
  • Requirement class determines the account assignment category
  • Account assignment category influences whether the system expects a WBS element, sales order, or cost center

If the strategy type doesn’t align with the WBS-based planning, the system may default to a different order type or ignore the PSP.

Next go to OPPE, and check whether MRP Group to Order type is mapped. Finally, in OPU5, check whether Planned Order profiles are configured for Plant, Order type and Production Scheduler.

entry.title: Re: How to Set Up Automatic Login in SAP
entry.content:
Hello,

You can use the SAP Webgui to log into the SAP system, create the VB scripts to access the URL and pass the user credentials.

VB script

______

set a = createobject("wscript.shell")
a.run "SAP WEBGUI URL"
wscript.sleep(2000)
a.sendkeys("User ID")
a.sendkeys chr(9)
wscript.sleep (2000)
a.sendkeys("password")
a.sendkeys "{Enter}"
wscript.quit

------------

Regards

Sriram

entry.title: Re: How to use underdelivery tolerence in project stock r...
entry.content:
The underdelivery tolerance maintained in VD51 or in the Sales Order Shipping tab will work for standard Make-to-Order (MTO) strategy (e.g., Strategy 20), but I don't think, it will work automatically for Make-to-Project (MTP) scenarios.

Why because, the key differences between MTP and MTO are

  • MTP uses account assignment category Q (project stock), which changes how requirements are handled.
  • In MTP, the system treats the sales order requirement as project demand, and MRP plans it based on project stock availability, not sales order tolerance.
  • The underdelivery tolerance logic is not inherently linked to project stock planning, unless custom logic is added.

For your Requirement Class Z81, check whether '1' is maintained for Consumption indicator and Planning indicator. Still this may not prevent planned order creation unless the system sees the tolerance as a hard limit. Though you have correctly maintained the Lot-sizing Procedure with Under delivery tolerance ticked, this setup does not block planned order creation for project stock unless the system is explicitly told to do so.

To enforce underdelivery tolerance in MTP:

You may need to implement a BAdI or user exit in MRP logic (e.g., MD_CHANGE_MRP_DATA) to suppress planned order creation if available stock meets tolerance. This is especially relevant for project stock, where standard logic doesn’t apply tolerance checks.

entry.title: Re: Change Revenue Recognition key in Professional Servic...
entry.content:
To my knowledge, as of now, SAP does not offer a standard mass update tool for revenue recognition keys across multiple WBS elements in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition – Projects app. The app is designed for individual updates, which can be time-consuming if you have many billing elements.

One alternative which SAP provides configuration tools that can help automate recognition key assignment going forward, but not retroactively. You can try with SSCUI 104054 – Define Replacement Rules for Recognition Keys which allows runtime replacement of recognition keys based on accounting principles. Useful if you want to switch keys dynamically without manual edits.

The other one is SSCUI 102517 – Derivation of Recognition Key for Projects both of which are mentioned in the SAP Help

entry.title: Re: How can I repair corrupt database
entry.content: If the database is inconsistent and unload fails, it’s likely the two affected tables have physical corruption in their data pages. SQL Anywhere doesn’t have many built-in repair options beyond dbvalid or unloading from a backup. Since you don’t have a backup, you’ll need to try a specialized recovery tool. Stellar Repair for MS SQL is made for repairing corrupted database files and can sometimes recover selected tables from damaged DBs, even if unload fails. It’s paid, but for production-critical tables it might be worth it. Otherwise, you could attempt to export unaffected rows with SELECT INTO before the engine hits the bad pages

entry.title: Re: Advanced Event Mesh - Partitioned Queues : One Queue for All
entry.content:
Hi Anuj,

You will still have restrictions; but if you design like this:

- Have a partitioned queue, consumed by multiple (let's say 5 consumers. They can be instance of the same app).

- depending on your work order number, it is always consumed by the same consumer(app instance). WorkOrder1->Consumer1 . WO2->C2 WO3->C5 etc.) regardless of the statuses.

- If your consumer knows to handle the statuses (it should know), then there wouldn't be  a problem.

- If smt. wrong happens for WO1-related messages, then C1 can handle it while C5 is still getting WO3 related messages. C1 of course should handle the problem of WO1 and continue getting these messages. 

Limit for this scenario is the number of consumers-partitions that you attach to the pipeline.

Baris

entry.title: Re: Difference in object list header data: previously / Y...
entry.content:
Check SAP note 3487322 which indicates the issue is about Serial Numbers. As recommended in that SAP note, you can run the report ZZ_ADJUST_ANZSN from SAP note 119719. If that is not the case, go through the below.

This error usually indicates a mismatch in the object list header data between the outbound delivery and the inbound delivery creation process. Specifically:

  • The object list (OL) in the outbound delivery contains a reference (e.g., /YY1114)
  • When SPED triggers the inbound delivery, SAP expects the same reference
  • If the reference changes or is missing, SAP throws IO308

This can happen due to changes in the delivery header data after PGI, or incorrect or missing configuration in output determination or inconsistent partner or plant assignments between supplying and receiving plants.

Check your output type whether routine 408 is assigned and ensure, the Partner Functions and Plants are assigned. Next go to VL03N, input that delivery reference and execute. From there go to Header > Status > Object List. Ensure no manual changes were made post-PGI. Of course, as you know, after PGI, most core logistics data (quantities, items, batch numbers, etc.) are locked. But SAP still allows changes to certain header-level or administrative fields, such as:

  • Texts (delivery header or item texts)
  • Output determination (e.g., adding or reprocessing output types like SPED)
  • Partner functions (in rare cases, if not fully locked)
  • Status fields (if updated via user exit or enhancement)
  • Object list entries (if manipulated via custom logic or interface)
